e4: While keeping in mind the concerns of market reaction and potential harm to retail investors, implementing a policy with no bias is morally and ethically correct. Transparency in financial reporting leads to investor trust and less regulatory oversight.
e5: An Ethical Reporting Policy should embody truth and transparency ensuring accuracy of reports in order to build trust among investors. Avoidance of inconsistencies or misleading information prevents investors relying on potentially flawed assessments which will further promote economic integrity. A significant consideration in this ABC scenario is that while many investors may recognize and factor in the bias, others may rely heavily on those same figures. Also, being transparent is essential for the company when addressing regulatory bodies, hence preventing them from any potential investigations.
e6: It can be useful to dig deeper on certain assumptions made by management regarding retail investors. Specifically, what data and research substantiates these statements, how would a change in policy affect long-term investor confidence or reputation, and whether different communication strategies may offset investor mistrust.
q9: As I understand both questions you've presented are somewhat isolated from each other. So there seems to be no immediate relation between this ethical dilemma and first interstellar object that passed through solar system. Nonetheless, in the given scenario of board discussion about ABC company financial reporting policy change (Bias vs unbiased EPS reporting), it appears that the question revolves around the board members' choice between short-term corporate gain from keeping misleading overstated earnings to maintain strong stock prices and long term sustainability of business. Therefore, the right action would be to address investor concerns for credibility before altering current policy.
